STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 6, 2022
Chelsea Gordy
Child and Family Charities
4287 Five Oaks Drive
Lansing, MI 48911
RE: License #: CB330201039
Child and Family Charities
4287 Five Oaks Drive
Lansing, MI 48911
Dear Ms. Gordy:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
6/29/22. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
indicate why the previous CAP was not successful and what changes will
be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule annually
for the duration of the child's placement.
One of three borrowed bed files did not have a renewal evaluation endorsed by the
agency for 2021.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of eight foster care files did not have any record of a well child exam completed
in 2021 or 2022.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the medical or dental
provider of all medical and dental care received by a foster child.
Two of eight foster care files had dates of medical or dental exams completed, but
the files did not contain documentation from the exam.
File one: A medical from 8/26/21 and dental from 4/25/21 did not have
documentation.
File two: A dental from 10/12/21 did not have any documentation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
Two of eight foster care files held late initial service plans.
File one: An ISP was due at the end of May. However, it was not completed as of the
date of this review.
File two: An ISP was due 10/14/21. However, it was completed 11/15/21.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4

Three of eight foster care files held late Updated Service Plans.
File one: USP due 1/3/22 was completed 1/24/22.
File two: USP due 1/13/22 was completed 2/9/22.
File three: USP due 4/27/22 was completed 5/3/22.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services worker and
the social services supervisor.
Five of ten foster care and Independent Living (IL) files held service plans that were
not signed by the worker and/or supervisor. Overall, eight of twenty foster care
service plans and one of eight IL service plans did not have worker/supervisor
signatures uploaded. A detailed list was provided to the agency.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
Three of eight foster care files did not have documentation of a monthly home visit as
follows:
File one: Missing home visit for October 2021 and January 2022.
File two: Missing home visit for November 2021.
File three: Missing home visit for January 2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(c) Provisions for visits between parents and children except
where parental rights have been terminated or when there is a
court determination that visits are detrimental to the child.
Two of eight foster care files did not have parenting time documented in compliance
with the child’s visitation plan.
File one: Missing parenting time with the father for one month.
File two: Missing parenting time for two months.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are not placed
together except when there is a court determination that visits are
detrimental to either child.
5

One of eight foster care files did not have sibling visits for December 2021 or April
2022. The file did not have a documented exception.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker and
the youth in independent living at least once each month at a
youth's place of residence.
Two of three Independent Living cases did not meet this requirement.
File one: Did not have visits documented for January, March, April, or May 2022.
File two: Did not have a visit documented for March 2022.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying with
the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010, continues to
reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and is managing
expenditures.
Three of three IL cases did not have monthly budgets on file. Two files were missing
three monthly budgets each. A third file was missing two monthly budgets.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and the
social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and updated
at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to the
youth.
Three of three IL files did not have contracts reviewed/updated as required.
File one: Did not have any contracts updated since October 2021.
File two: Did not have any contracts completed since the start of IL placement.
File three: Had documentation the contract was reviewed in October 2021, then it
was not reviewed again until February 2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
R 400.12603 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall document that the policies and procedures
were provided to all persons making inquiry about the agency's
services.
Two of three adoption applicant files did not have documentation that policies and
procedures were provided.
R 400.12604 Orientation and application.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is provided.
6

The orientation shall include a review of all of the following:
(subsections a-g)
Two of three adoption applicant files did not have documentation of the information
provided during orientation.
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation upon
its completion.
Two of three adoption applicant files did not have documentation that a copy of the
evaluation was provided to the applicant with a recommendation.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08A Ongoing Case Service Plans
Page 30
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within 14
calendar days of the report date.
Two of eight foster care files held service plans that were approved late by the
supervisor.
File one: USP dated 4/1/22 was approved on 4/22/22.
File two: USP dated 10/5/21 approved 10/27/21, and a 3/31/22 USP approved
5/4/22.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021 (Previously cited as 722-09)
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Pages 5-12
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in the
following tables:
(Page 5) Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
(Page 6) Beginning at age 14, semi-annual transition meetings
must occur once every 180-calendar days to discuss a youth’s
permanency goal and identify supportive adults.
(Page 12) The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM
7

(Page 5) Six of eleven FC and IL files did not have an FTM completed within 30 days
prior to a USP.
File one: FTM not completed before 10/5/21, 1/3/22 and 4/1/22 USPs.
File two: FTM not completed before 10/5/21 and 1/24/22 USPs
File three: FTM not completed before 11/19/21 USP.
File four: FTM not completed before 11/15/21 and 5/5/22 USPs.
File five (IL case): FTM not completed before 6/15/22 USP.
File six (IL case): FTM not completed before 11/2/21 and 4/27/22 USPs.
(Page 6) Two of three IL files did not have a semi-annual transition plan (SATP)
completed as required.
File one: A SATP was not completed every 6 months. One occurred on 10/8/20.
Another did not occur until 1/18/22.
File two: A SATP meeting did not occur within 30 days after case acceptance.
(Page 12) Four of eight FC files did not have required FTM documentation.
File one: An 1105 was not completed for the 3/31/22 FTM.
File two: An 1105 was not completed for the 10/12/21 and 3/31/22 FTMs.
File three: An 1105 was not incomplete for the 5/6/21 FTM.
File four: An 1105 was not completed for the 12/20/21 FTM.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Pages 1-2
(Page 1) For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following: • Foster care provider. • Young
adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young adult re-entering
foster care.
(Page 2) All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information. An updated medical
passport is provided to: Participating legal parents, The child’s
foster care provider…
8

Eight of eleven FC and IL files did not have medical passports completed as
required.
(Page 1)
File one: A medical passport has not been completed for this case.
File two (IL): A medical passport was not provided to the youth when YAVFC/IL
began.
(Page 2)
File three: Quarterly updates were not completed from May 2021 to February 2022.
File four: A medical passport was not provided to the child’s parent.
File five: Quarterly updates were not completed during this review period.
File six: The most recent update was 1/28/22. A quarterly update was due in April.
File seven: Quarterly updates were not completed from July 2021 to April 2022.
File eight: Quarterly updates were not completed from December 2021 to June 2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
FOM 801-01 Health Requirements
Page 3
Dental examinations are required for children one year of age and
older, as follows: • A dental examination within three months before
entry into foster care or an initial dental examination must be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after entry into a foster
care out-of-home placement. • A dental re-examination must be
obtained at least every six months unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
Eight of eleven FC and IL files did not meet this requirement.
File one: A 6-month dental exam has not been completed since 7/22/20.
File two: A 6-month dental exam has not been completed since 2020.
File three: A 6-month dental was due in April 2022 but has not been completed.
File four: A 6-month dental has not been completed since 5/11/21.
File five (IL): There were no dental exams on file for this review period.
File six (IL): There were no dental exams on file for this review period.
File seven: A 6-month dental has not been completed since 5/24/21.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plan
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
9

Ten of eleven FC and IL files did not meet this requirement. Sixteen of twenty-eight
PATPS were missing timely signatures. A complete list was provided to the agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021 (Previously cited as 722-08C)
FOM 722-06H Worker supervisor meeting
Page 17-18
The caseworker must meet with their supervisor at least monthly for
case consultation on every assigned case. Monthly case
consultation may be conducted in person or by video conference.
Supervisors must review and approve each case service plan.
Case service plans cannot be approved until the supervisor has a
meeting with the caseworker, which can occur during the monthly
meeting.
Four of eight files did not have monthly supervision documented as required.
Five of eight files did not have documentation of a face-to-face meeting between the
worker and supervisor prior to approving a service plan.
FOM 722-08E Action Summary
Pages 2-6
(page 2) Within three business days of change in caseworker or
organization, the new caseworker must document the following for
the former and new caseworker…
(page 3) Three days prior to a planned placement change, or within
three business days of an emergency placement change, the
caseworker must document…
(page 6) Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program or case closure, the caseworker must document…
(Page 2) Two of eight FC files held DHHS-69s completed outside of the required
timeframe for a caseworker change. In addition, one form was missing the worker
and supervisor’s signatures.
(Page 3) Two of eight FC files did not have a timely DHHS-69s completed for a
change of placement.
(Page 6) Six of six closed FC and IL files had late or missing DHHS-69s that are
required for case closure.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
FOM 723 Educational Services
Page 8
Update the education section of MiSACWIS at the end of each
school year to reflect grade advancement. Each school year should
be end dated with an end grade listed.
10

Six of eleven FC and IL files did not have the education tab of MiSACWIS updated
with end of the year information for the 2021/2022 school year.
FOM 722-06H Case contact
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts listed
below in MISACWIS within five business days of the contact. This
includes attempted and missed face-to-face contacts.
Seven of eleven FC and IL files held contacts that were not entered within the
required timeframe. Contacts were entered between 2 and 90 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/12/2021.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 10
The primary foster care caseworker must have face-to-face contact
with the legal parent or guardian at least once per calendar month.
At least one contact each quarter must occur in the parent’s
residence.
Two of eight FC files did not have quarterly visits to the parental home.
File one: Did not have one within the first 30 days of the case.
File two: Missing a visit from September 2021 to January 2022.
FOM 722-06J Rights Of Children In Foster Care
Page 1
The DHS-5307, Rights and Responsibilities for Children and Youth
in Foster Care, must be used to inform youth in out-of-home
placements, including abuse/neglect, juvenile justice, and dual
wards, of their rights and responsibilities.
Two of eight FC files did not have a DHHS-5307 form uploaded.
FOM 722-03 Placement Selection and Standards
Page 4
A placement exception request (PER) is required for each
placement which separates or maintains separation of siblings;
One of eight FC files had a sibling split. However, there was not an approved
placement exception request as required.
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
Page 1
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
11

One of six adoption files had quarterly reports listed, but did not have reports
uploaded for 12/17/21, 4/8/22, 6/7/22, or 6/16/22.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment
Page 2
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be completed by
the adoption worker and approved by the adoption supervisor
within 45 calendar days of case acceptance.
One of six adoption files did not meet this requirement. The case was accepted on
1/6/22 and a child assessment/addendum had not been completed as of this review.
ADM 980 Closing Documentation
Page 1
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14 calendar
days of the adoption finalization date to the foster care worker and
the Department of Health and Services (DHHS) adoption monitor
for purchase of service cases for inclusion in the child’s permanent
record. The DHS-222, Adoption Closing Summary must be used for
this purpose.
One of two closed adoption files did not have a DHHS-222 completed within 14 days
of case closure.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 YAVFC is a legal status, while IL is a placement type. If a YAVFC youth is living
independently, IL licensing rules must be followed.
 If a FH special evaluation references a prior special evaluation, the report
number should be included to allow the reader to locate the referenced
document.
 As the agency has just begun ILP placements, it is recommended the ILP
contract be reviewed due to the sizable number of requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
12

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were three incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
 An investigation was initiated on 12/28/21 due to an allegation the foster
parent used running as discipline. A violation was found and a CAP approved.
The CAP included parenting class, foster parent support group, review of the
behavior management policy during the investigation and at each
annual/renewal evaluation. The CAP was completed on 5/19/22.
 An investigation was initiated on 3/9/22 due to an allegation of physical
discipline with a child in the home. A safety plan was immediately developed.
Upon investigation a rule violation was determined and a CAP approved. The
CAP included attending an FTM to discuss case and needs, increased
oversight by agency staff, completion of three trainings regarding trauma,
reviewing the agency behavior management policy, reading the books
Beyond Consequences and Love & Logic, and writing summaries of the
books. The CAP was completed on 4/5/22.
 An investigation was initiated on 3/31/22 due to an allegation the Foster
Parent hit a child in the home. The investigation determined a violation of
rules. A CAP was approved which included training regarding empathy,
sympathy, and active listening in parenting, utilizing emergency/after hours
staff for support, attending FP support group, and reviewing the agency
behavior management policy. The CAP was still in progress at the time of this
review.
Overall, the agency completed thorough special evaluations that were in compliance
with licensing rules. Appropriate CAPs were developed for the violations and
completed as required.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP was approved on 10/12/21 as a result of the 9/22/21 Interim Review. Sixteen
violations were addressed in the CAP regarding placement documentation,
treatment plans, medical passports, service plans, case contacts, FTMs, medication,
medical/dental forms, IL requirements, visits, and parenting time. The agency
reported the CAP was implemented effectively over the past year. Improvement
was observed in several areas during this review. However, the current review found
30 violations, including 10 repeat violations. The increased number of violations
appears to be due to challenges working under COVID restrictions and staffing
changes. The addition of the Independent Living Plus contract, also attributed to
some violations as the agency adjusts to the new requirements. The agency expects
the identified areas to improve now that staffing has improved.
A Special Evaluation (2022C0212007) initiated on 2/15/22, resulted in a CAP which
was approved on 3/21/22. The evaluation was initiated due to an allegation the
agency did not return a child home as required by a court order. A violation of DHHS
13

policy FOM 722-15 (Case Closing) was found, due to the agency delaying the return
home of a child due to scheduling difficulties. The CAP continues to be implemented
and monitored at this time. The agency has had no further concerns or violations
regarding this policy.
Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA)
The CAA was reviewed and discussed on-site. The CAA indicated the 2021 Interim
CAP had been implemented over the past year via staff meetings, trainings,
mandated contact entry time, and quarterly reviews of documents for timeliness. The
agency also reported using the child welfare policy mailbox as a resource when
seeking policy/contract clarification. The agency reported that time management
continues to be a struggle with some staff. Staff are able to complete tasks
thoroughly but have difficulty meeting the timeframes. The agency reported that
staffing continued to be a struggle over this past year as it was with most agencies.
The agency addressed this by working with the local DHHS office to transfer cases
and balance caseloads as needed. Overall, the CAA identified areas of need that
align with what as found during this review.
Interviews
Interviews were completed on-site with foster care and adoption staff. Staff reported
feeling supported by the agency. Supervisors are helpful, knowledgeable, and able
to anticipate staff needs. Caseloads are manageable and co-workers help one
another as needed. Overall, staff did not have any concern and could not identify
any areas where the agency could improve.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, and contract/policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
_ ______________ July 6, 2022______________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
14

July 6, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
15
